div.title: Mapping COBIT 5 process reference model into OSCAL
div.p: See COBIT 5, Enabling Business Processes p. 25 for a description of the process reference model.

stmt.p: COBIT 5 distinguishes groups of controls in five different domains.
Combines the inherited domain code with a sequential two-digit number (padded zeros) e.g. EDM01 for the first control in domain EDM (Evaluate, Direct and Monitor).
A normative description of the control (process).
The fact that this is an IT-related control enhancement is captured by including a property prop with @class='scope' with the value IT.

The control enhancement used to describe this is the same as is used for the next table, the process-related goal table. Note however that the IT-related goals (as indicated by the scope property) are implicit cross-links to elsewhere in OSCAL.
Like IT-related goals, each process-related goal has a number, title and Metrics section. In this case, however, the property prop with @class='scope' has the value process.
Presents a map of responsibilities, role category classifications for responsible, accountable, consulted, informed.
Since the table allocates the values across processes (control enhancements), its contents are allocated to those elements (i.e. disbursed) in the OSCAL.

control.prop: Governance or Management Practice RACI assignments

stmt.p: Note that according to COBIT (p. 26) not all practice inputs are represented, but only those that are specific to particular practices. So if a practice has an input due to another practice having all or all EDM as an output (for example), such an input is not listed. Only inputs designated for this particular control (practice) are indicated.
Implicit inputs can be detected by querying.
